entry.title: Passed Google Professional Cloud Architect on 25th August
entry.content:
Today it marks a key milestone for my multi-cloud journey. I have passed all professional level solutions architect certificates by AWS, AZURE and GOOGLE. Have always been planning to do it. During COVID19, it’s probably the best time to complete this challenge.

The exam only has PASS/FAIL. It takes 7-10 days to eventually receive the certificate from Google.

Google Cloud Next OnAir sessions started from July. Meanwhile, there are free Google PCK Sprint classes which offer related topics aligned with Next OnAir. It’s like a free buffet with all you can eat Google Cloud technologies. I attended all of them. On top of it, I got free qwiklabs credits. Timing is perfect and I really benefit a lot from these events.

I still feel AWS SAP is the hardest exam. GOOGLE exam only has 50 questions. It’s abundant study material. The official guidebook has detailed for every topic. The case studies are in provision before the exam. Qwiklabs has so many labs to practice and helps you understand each technology component. Coursera provides two courses, one for exam preparation and another is for core technologies. In addition, you can follow Next OnAir, listen to current industries adoption and best practices.

Looking forward, since I have passed Azure security, time to clear this topic for AWS and GOOGLE in September.

Useful information:

  1. Google PCK Sprint: Core Infrastructure

  2. Official Google Cloud Certified Professional Cloud Architect Study Guide Paperback 1

  3. Coursera: Preparing for the Google Cloud Professional Cloud Architect Exam

  4. Coursera: Architecting with Google Compute Engine Specialization

  5. Braincert: Professional Cloud Architect Practice Exam 1

  6. Offical GCP site

  7. Google Next OnAir

entry.title: Passed Azure Security Engineer Associate AZ500 Exam on 13th August
entry.content:
It’s the new version of AZ500 and released on 29th July. I guess I am first batch of people taking the exam. My score is 823.

There are 4 buckets to study: application security, network security, computing/resource security and Active Directory. Not a very difficult topic to me so obviously it didn’t take me much time for preparation.

Although there are common industry best practices like bastion host, least privilege, defence in depth, etc. nowadays it’s a trend that more and more cloud vendors start to implement NLP for cloud security. It’s like a intelligent agent backed by machine learning to automatically study and identify malicious patterns and bahaviors, and proactively contain the risk. I guess it’s pretty easy to sell such ‘security as a service’ concept and charge a subscription fee. It’s not going to be cheap though.

Useful information:

  1. Official site

  2. Microsoft Azure Virtual Training Day (webinar series) from 6th July (Google it)

  3. Linux Academy: Microsoft Azure Security Technologies (LA) by Shawn Johnson

entry.title: Passed Microsoft Azure Architect Design AZ301 Exam on 4th August
entry.content:
Plus AZ300, now I am officially Azure Solutions Architect Expert! My hard work is paid off. So happy~

AZ301 is very much alike AZ300 but more focused on solutions design. I spent a lot time to practice using my free $200 credits. The official site has rich material from case studies to sand box practices. I really like some high quality labs which provide step by step instructions to build things like a data warehouse with Synapse Analytics or a scalable application through scale sets. I can feel the logic behind how to design a sound solution with key Azure technologies.

My AWS SAP background does help me a lot to speed up whole learning process. I feel AWS, AZURE and GOOGLE are not mutually exclusive in term of core cloud technologies, data encryption in transit and at rest, eleven nines of storage durability, virtual network design, a horizontally scalable, globally-distributed, multi-model database, etc. I think the key competition is how to create a bullet proof and high performance solution by combining various ingredients to meet industry specific usage scenarios. I always say technology without massive adoption is incompetent. If you watch a few AWS re:Invent video clips and check out AWS customers’ cloud journey, you shall know what I mean.

Microsoft Azure Virtual Training Day (webinar series) started from 6th July. There are plenty virtual sessions covering various Azure topics. The downside is that it’s in US timezone so I have to stay awake at 2am Australian east time. ;(

My exam has no labs. In addition to multiple choice questions, a few case studies, some drag and drop and hotspots. My final score is 842.

Useful information:

  1. AZ301 official site

  2. Microsoft Azure Virtual Training Day (webinar series) from 6th July (Google it)

  3. Linux Academy: Microsoft Azure Architect Design - Exam AZ-301 (LA) by James Lee

entry.title: Passed Microsoft Azure Architect Technologies AZ300 Exam on 23rd July
entry.content:
The preparation for AZ300 is pretty straight forward to me right after AWS SAP exam. The study path is very identical like storage, computing, security, etc. But there are huge differences in underlying technologies, for example, Azure Cosmos DB vs. AWS DynamoDB. I feel very intrigued to find out how things stack up differently. I like integrated Cloud Shell from Azure portal and it’s very easy to switch between Powershell and Bash.

Also AZ300 is very case study oriented. I like AZ300 official site which provides hands-on labs and case scenarios analysis. Comparing with AWS SAP, I feel AZ300 is more practical and less theory. You need to have intermediate programming skills and understand Microsoft technology stack. The exam has labs and coding related questions to test your real operating skills.

The Azure material at Linux Academy is OK but not as robust as AWS related courses. It breaks up Azure technologies by components unlike the case studies from AZ300 official site which is focusing on real solutions design and how to assemble a combination of Azure technologies.

entry.title: AWS SAP DONE
entry.content:
My second AWS badge. Not the hardest exam so far but SAP exam does seriously test your speed and accuracy. You need to be very proficient in key concepts, connect dots and design right solutions. I heard a lot people saying it’s a difficult exam. I feel I prepared a bit too much. It’s like 5 weeks after my associate exam on 27th May.

Just found out the founders of A Cloud Guru are Aussie brothers. Inspiring story! A Cloud Guru acquired Linux Academy in December 2019. If you wanna study cloud technology, that’s the place to be. I like the logic and depth of their course material which covers every mainstream cloud product in the market like AWS, Google and Azure. On a side note, SAP exam is very time compressed. I feel 500 hours practice does not guarantee to pass exam especially for people with English as a second language. So online training/practice and exam preparation should be paralleled tasks.

I think the study path follows a similar structure [computing, storage, database, networking, security, migration, SAM, DevOps] for every cloud product. Under technical facade, we have cloud native, SAM and CI/CD implementation. AWS has No.1 market share for a reason. It’s widely used by every industry vertical, accumulates tens of thousands of hours of operating experience and provides best service packages for customers and partners. Technology without massive implementation is not competent.

I plan to pass Azure Solution Architect by July and GCP PSA by August. Then I will deep dive AWS Big Data, Machine Learning and Security plus DevOps. Hope to sign off by 2020.

Some good material for SAP exam,

  1. Practical exam
  2. AWS White paper (I almost downloaded all of them)
  3. Cheat sheets

entry.title: Project Management
entry.content:
Part of my continuous study plan and try to stay ahead of popular project management practices in industry, this is part of my achievement so far.

The Scrum Guide made by Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber only has 19 pages. It doesn’t mean it’s easy to execute but it’s just a very top level introduction. You could easily write thousands pages of documents for various industries and organization functions to implement Scrum and that part needs to be explored. Have been closely looking at case studies cross industry sectors, how they go through the transformation process, I would say they follow 60% of common practice plus 40% tailored approach. When everything-as-a-service business model propels, the only thing you present to customers is that piece of APP made of binary code. I don’t see tratidional corporate hierarchy and top-down dependency fit in current business context any more.

I have been with different institutes like PMI, Scrum Alliance and SAFe and learn their best practices. They are not mutually exclusive but provide different tools to help you implement. Agility, Autonomy and Simplicity would be ultimate architecture for modern organization to scale. The people organization needs to be innovated. Corporate silos need to be broken down. Value creation needs to be measurable on daily basis through technology and automation. That’s what scrum is all about.

  2. Scrum Alliance Certified Scrum Master

  3. Scrum Alliance Certified Product Owner

  4. PMI Project Management Professional

entry.title: Completed four NANOs at Udacity
entry.content:
Have known Udacity for quite a while but didn’t have chance to try it out. During “Great Lockdown”, I finally have time to sit down and finish four NANOs.

Unlike Coursera or some other trainings I did in the past, Udacity is very hands-on with plenty projects in Python coding, DevOps and AI/Deep Learning. There are not much theories. The course material is designed to help you complete those projects.

Usually it takes three months to finish one NANO degree given about 10 hours workload per week. But I chose to pay only one month subscription and try to finish it without further renew. Overall it’s quite a challenging experience. I feel it’s quite difficult to stay motivated, study independendly and look for answers by self when got stuck in projects.

Deep Learning is probably the best course material I have ever seen in the market these days. Just be aware you need to understand discrete mathematics, algebra and have intermediate level of Python programming. But don’t worry, Udacity finds ways to light you up when you go through the course. Personally I feel even without strong coding experience, you still can give it try. AI/Deep Learning is very popular subject. These days even a product manager still needs to know some fundamental concepts like CNN and underlying instruments like AWS SageMaker to implement the product.

Predictive Analytics for Business is all about Alteryx. Alteryx is such a powerful analytics tool integrated with R. I like the workflow design and off the shelf packages for tasks like data wrangling, A/B testing, time series forecasting and clustering. Alteryx makes analytics much easier with clear logic. That’s why a lot consulting firms are using it.

Cloud DevOps Engineer introduces some best engineering practices in industry like Kubernetes, pipeline and CI/CD. There are some projects implemented on top of AWS which is such a popular platform. From here, I decided to take AWS Solution Architect exam and get to know about this amazing product.

Other than that, I start to use Github heavily. Github starts to become one stop shop for developers with IDE, CD/CD and release control all in one place. I actually build my personal site on top of Github.

Please see the list of NANOs in case you are interested.

  1. Deep Learning
  2. AI Product Manager
  3. Predictive Analytics for Business
  4. Cloud DevOps Engineer
